sections.title: Translation of Parabola
sections.content: If f(x) = x^2 then f(x-h) + k = (x-h)^2 + k. The graph y = (x-h)^2 + k has the same shape as y = x^2. It can be produced from y = x^2 by a translation h units to the right and k units upwards. This shifts the vertex of the parabola from the origin O(0,0) to (h,k).

sections.title: Translation Rules
sections.content: For y = f(x) + b, the effect of b is to translate the graph vertically through b units. If b > 0 it moves upwards. If b < 0 it moves downwards. For y = f(x-a), the effect of a is to translate the graph horizontally through a units. If a > 0 it moves to the right. If a < 0 it moves to the left. For y = f(x-a) + b, the graph is translated horizontally a units and vertically b units. We say it is translated by the vector (a, b).

sections.problem: Consider the graph of y = f(x) alongside. On separate axes, draw the graphs of: a) y = f(x) + 2, b) y = f(x+4)

solution.part_a: The graph of y = f(x) + 2 is found by translating y = f(x) 2 units upwards.
solution.part_b: The graph of y = f(x+4) is found by translating y = f(x) 4 units to the left.

sections.title: Stretching Rules
sections.content: y = pf(x), p > 0 is a vertical stretch of y = f(x) with scale factor p and invariant x-axis. Each point becomes p times its previous distance from the x-axis. If p > 1, points move further away from the x-axis. If 0 < p < 1, points move closer to the x-axis. y = f(qx), q > 0 is a horizontal stretch of y = f(x) with scale factor 1/q and invariant y-axis. Each point becomes 1/q times its previous distance from the y-axis. If q > 1, points move closer to the y-axis. If 0 < q < 1, points move further away from the y-axis.

sections.problem: Consider the graph of y = f(x) alongside. On separate axes, draw the graphs of: a) y = 3f(x), b) y = f(2x)

solution.part_a: The graph of y = 3f(x) is a vertical stretch of y = f(x) with scale factor 3.
solution.part_b: The graph of y = f(2x) is a horizontal stretch of y = f(x) with scale factor 1/2.

sections.problem: The function g(x) results when y = 1/x is transformed by a vertical stretch with scale factor 2, followed by a translation of (3, -2). a) Write an expression for g(x) in the form g(x) = (ax+b)/(cx+d). b) Find the asymptotes of y = g(x). c) Sketch y = g(x).

solution.part_a: Under a vertical stretch with scale factor 2, f(x) becomes 2f(x). So 1/x becomes 2(1/x) = 2/x. Under a translation of (3, -2), f(x) becomes f(x-3) - 2. So 2/x becomes 2/(x-3) - 2 = (2-2(x-3))/(x-3) = (-2x+8)/(x-3). g(x) is a rational function (linear/linear).
solution.part_b: The asymptotes of y = 1/x are x = 0 and y = 0. These are unchanged by the stretch, and shifted (3, -2) by the translation. The vertical asymptote is x = 3 and the horizontal asymptote is y = -2.

sections.title: Reflection Rules
sections.content: For y = -f(x), we reflect y = f(x) in the x-axis. For y = f(-x), we reflect y = f(x) in the y-axis.

sections.problem: Consider the graph of y = f(x) alongside. On separate axes, draw the graphs of: a) y = -f(x), b) y = f(-x)

solution.part_a: The graph of y = -f(x) is found by reflecting y = f(x) in the x-axis.
solution.part_b: The graph of y = f(-x) is found by reflecting y = f(x) in the y-axis.

Consider a function f(x). a) What function results if y = f(x) is reflected in the x-axis, then translated through (3, -1), then stretched vertically with scale factor 2? b) Fully describe the transformations which map y = f(x) onto y = 3f(2(x-1)) - 2.

solution.part_a: f(x) -> -f(x) [reflection in x-axis] -> -f(x-3) - 1 [translation (3,-1)] -> 2(-f(x-3) - 1) [vertical stretch scale factor 2]. The resulting function is -2f(x-3) - 2.
solution.part_b: f(x) -> 3f(x) [vertical stretch scale factor 3] -> 3f(2x) [horizontal stretch scale factor 1/2] -> 3f(2(x-1)) - 2 [translation (1,-2)].

sections.title: Even Functions
sections.content: Consider the function f(x) = x^2. Notice that f(-3) = f(3) = 9. In fact, f(-x) = f(x) for all x. We know this is true since f(-x) = (-x)^2 = x^2 = f(x). We say that f(x) = x^2 is an even function. A function f(x) is even if f(-x) = f(x) for all x in the domain of f. The graph of an even function is symmetrical about the y-axis.

sections.title: Odd Functions
sections.content: Consider the function f(x) = x^3. Notice that f(-2) = -8 and f(2) = 8, so f(-2) = -f(2). In fact, f(-x) = -f(x) for all x. We know this is true since f(-x) = (-x)^3 = (-1)^3 x^3 = -x^3 = -f(x). We say that f(x) = x^3 is an odd function. A function f(x) is odd if f(-x) = -f(x) for all x in the domain of f. The graph of an odd function has rotational symmetry about the origin.

sections.problem: Determine whether each function is even, odd, or neither: a) f(x) = 1/x, b) g(x) = x^4 + x^2, c) h(x) = x^2 - 2x + 3

solution.part_a: f(x) = 1/x. f(-x) = 1/(-x) = -1/x = -f(x). Therefore f(x) is an odd function.
solution.part_b: g(x) = x^4 + x^2. g(-x) = (-x)^4 + (-x)^2 = x^4 + x^2 = g(x). Therefore g(x) is an even function.
solution.part_c: h(x) = x^2 - 2x + 3. h(-x) = (-x)^2 - 2(-x) + 3 = x^2 + 2x + 3. This is neither h(x) nor -h(x). Therefore h(x) is neither even nor odd.
